'''Gregory Serper''' ({{lang-ru|Григорий Юрьевич Серпер}}) (born September 14, 1969) is a [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grand Master]] of [[chess]]. <ref> "FIDE Chess Profile" https://ratings.fide.com/card.phtml?event=2012642 </ref>

He was born in [[Tashkent]], in the former [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic]] of the [[Soviet Union]] (present [[Uzbekistan]]). At age 6, he learned to play chess from his grandfather. In 1985, at age 16, he started studies at Moscow's famous Botvinnik-Kasparov Chess School.

During his military service in Novosibirsk, he attended the 27th [[World Junior Chess Championship]] held in 1988 in [[Adelaide]], [[Australia]]. In this strong tournament Serper took 3rd place with same score 9/13 as his opponents [[Lautier]], [[Ivanchuk]] and [[Gelfand]] who took 1st, 2nd and 4th place respectively.<ref>''Chess Informant'', Vol. 46, Šahovski Informator, p. 448</ref><ref>Here [http://www.chess.com/article/view/the-biggest-secret-of-the-soviet-chess-scool] you can find an interesting story about this tournament written by Serper himself. </ref>

In 1992, as a member of the Uzbekistan team, Serper won the [[silver medal]] in the [[30th Chess Olympiad]].

In January 1996 he moved with his family to the [[United States]]. In 1999, Serper won the [[World Open chess tournament|World Open tournament]] after drawing an [[List of chess terms#Armageddon|Armageddon]] [[playoff]] game as [[White and Black in chess|Black]] against [[Boris Gulko]], who had been one of nine players who had tied with Serper in the main event.<ref>Grandmasters Serper, Gulko, [[Vladimir Akopian]], [[Joel Benjamin]], [[Jaan Ehlvest]], [[Alexander Fishbein]], [[Igor Novikov (chess player)|Igor Novikov]], [[Alexander Shabalov]], [[Georgi Timoshenko]], and [[Alex Yermolinsky]] tied for first at 7-2 in the main event. Seven of those ten players chose to participate in a [[List of chess terms#Blitz|blitz]] playoff, which Serper and Gulko won with 5/6. Gulko and Serper then played the Armageddon game, with Gulko taking White and receiving six minutes to five minutes [[Chess handicap|time odds]], but giving draw odds to Serper. The game ended in a draw after 43 moves. [[Jerry Hanken]], "Serper Breaks Log Jam at WORLD OPEN", ''[[Chess Life]]'', October 1999, p. 33.</ref> In the same year, he advanced to the finals of the [[U.S. Chess Championship]] by defeating [[Alex Yermolinsky]] in the semifinals, but lost in the finals to Gulko.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A05E5D7103FF935A1575AC0A96F958260 Robert Byrne, Boris Gulko Wins U.S. Title, ''New York Times'', September 26, 1999]</ref>
{{chess notation|section=tocright}}

Gregory writes regular articles for [[Chess.com]] under the username "Gserper".

''[[Chess Informant|Chess Informant's]]'' panel of judges voted the following game the second-best game of the 666 games in Volume 59 of ''Chess Informant''.<ref>''Chess Informant'', Volume 60, Šahovski Informator, 1994, p. 6.</ref> [[Larry Christiansen]] rated it his sixth favorite attacking game of the 1990s.<ref>Larry Christiansen, ''Storming the Barricades'', Gambit Publications, 2000, p. 154. {{ISBN|1-901983-25-0}}.</ref> [[Yasser Seirawan]] wrote, "Can you imagine a game in which you [[sacrifice (chess)|sacrifice]] ... ''all'' of your [[List of chess terms#Piece|pieces]]? Toss in the [[Promotion (chess)|promotion]] of two [[Pawn (chess)|pawns]] as well and you have a game to last!<ref>Yasser Seirawan, ''Combinations'', Gloucester Publishers, 2006, p. 161. {{ISBN|1-85744-420-5}}.</ref>
 
Serper-Ioannis Nikolaidis, [[St. Petersburg]] Open 1993<ref>[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1289099 Serper-Nikolaidis, St. Petersburg Open 1993]</ref> '''1.c4 g6 2.e4 Bg7 3.d4 d6 4.Nc3 Nf6 5.Nge2 Nbd7 6.Ng3 c6 7.Be2 a6 8.Be3 h5 9.f3 b5 10.c5 dxc5 11.dxc5 Qc7 12.O-O h4 13.Nh1 Nh5 14.Qd2 e5 15.Nf2 Nf8[[Chess punctuation#?: Mistake|?]]''' Seirawan recommended 15...Nf4 16.Nd3! Bh6 17.a4! with advantage to White.<ref>Seirawan, p. 162.</ref> '''16.a4 b4 17.Nd5[[Chess punctuation#!: Good move|!]]''' Eschewing the quiet 17.Ncd1 or 17.Na2, White sacrifices a piece to obtain two mobile [[List of chess terms#Connected passed pawns|connected passed pawns]] on the fifth [[List of chess terms#Rank|rank]]. '''cxd5 18.exd5 f5 19.d6''' 19.Qxb4 would allow Black to complicate with 19...Rb8 20.Qa3 e4 with an obscure position. '''Qc6 20.Bb5[[Chess punctuation#‼: Brilliant move|!!]]''' Another sacrifice in order to stop Black from establishing a successful [[List of chess terms#Blockade|blockade]]. '''axb5 21.axb5 Qxb5''' Black returns some material in order to blockade White's pawn. White would be winning after 21...Qb7 22.c6 Rxa1 23.cxb7 Rxf1+ 24.Kxf1 Bxb7 25.Nd3 Nd7 26.Qc2 e4 27.Qc7, or 22...Qb8 23.b6 Rxa1 24.Rxa1 Bd7 25.Qd5! Nf6 26.c7. '''22.Rxa8 Qc6 23.Rfa1! f4 24.R1a7! Nd7''' Not 24...fxe3? 25.Qd5! Qxd5 26.Rxc8#. Now Black threatens to get his [[King (chess)|king]] to safety by [[castling]], so White sacrifices more material. '''25.Rxc8+!! Qxc8 26.Qd5! fxe3 27.Qe6+ Kf8 28.Rxd7! exf2+ 29.Kf1 Qe8 30.Rf7+!''' Yet another sacrifice to allow White's d-pawn to promote. After 30.Qxe8+? Kxe8 31.Re7+ Kf8 32.c6 Ng3+! 33.Kxf2 Nxf5, White cannot advance his passed pawns. '''Qxf7 31.Qc8+ Qe8 32.d7 Kf7 33.dxe8=Q+ Rxe8 34.Qb7+ Re7 35.c6! e4! 36.c7 e3 37.Qd5+ Kf6 38.Qd6+ Kf7 39.Qd5+ Kf6 40.Qd6+ Kf7 41.Qxe7+ Kxe7 42.c8=Q Bh6 43.Qc5+ Ke8 44.Qb5+ Kd8 45.Qb6+ Kd7 46.Qxg6 e2+ 47.Kxf2 Be3+! 48.Ke1! [[List of chess terms#Resign|1&ndash;0]]''' Notes based on those by Christiansen, Serper, and Seirawan.<ref>Christiansen, pp. 154-57.</ref><ref>''Chess Informant'', Volume 59, Šahovski Informator, 1994, game 620 (p. 335). {{ISBN|84-87301-91-6}}.</ref><ref>Seirawan, pp. 161-67.</ref>
